description: [Status: stable] [Name: if-tuple] [Message: If test is a tuple, which is always True] What it does Checks for if statements that use non-empty tuples as test conditions. Why is this bad? Non-empty tuples are always True, so an if statement with a non-empty tuple as its test condition will always pass. This is likely a mistake. Example if (False,): print("This will always run") Use instead: if False: print("This will never run")
